bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Luis B. Pogolotti, October 15, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] discusses the location of Camp Lazear and Building No. 1, expressing his doubts about the site Moran has discovered.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to Luis B. Pogolotti, October 15, 1940
div1.opener:
October 15, 1940
Mr. Luis Pogolotti
Calle Cuba 3
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Pogolotti:
div1.p:
I am sending a carbon of this to Mr. Moran, but he may have already
left.

I spent several more hours last night examining the photographs and
Moran's letter, and also the maps that you so kindly drew for me. At this distance
from Cuba, it is of course hard to make a final opinion as to whether you have indeed
found the remains of Building No. 1. I want very much to believe that you have,
but it is difficult for me to compare a couple of the photographs now made with
the old army photographs. The slope of the land just below the shack seems much
greater than that in the army photograph. Nevertheless, the size of the shack is
amazingly close to the one we are hunting for. Reed said that Building No. 1 faced
the south. I understand that this faces mostly south but slightly east. Reed did
not say it faced due south, so that that is not a serious objection. The one thing
that worried me last night was that Moran said the hole for the chimney was on the
left side as you faced the shack and your drawing places it on the left side. But
Dr. Agramonte's drawing in the Scientific Monthly for December, 1915, places the
stove on the right. It is of course possible that he might have made a mistake in
the drawing if he drew it many years after the incident. I just had a letter from
Dr. Agramonte's daughter yesterday, saying that she had found her father's original
drawing of the old building. It would be important to find out from her if possible,
whether these drawings were made by Dr. Agramonte in 1900 or not drawn until 1915
and then perhaps from memory. If the latter were the case, the placing of the stove
might easily have been wrong in the drawing. I have wondered if the building that
you found might have been Building No. 2, or Building No. 1 facing the other way,
but as you will see by the enclosed drawings, neither of these quite fit your own
drawing. In my letter of yesterday, I called your attention to Reed's statement
that Building No. 2 faced Building No. 1 eighty yards away, and wondered whether the
supposed ruins, that is, the remains of the cement floor where Building No. 2 was,
are in fact, eighty yards from the shack which you discovered.

For the above reasons, I cannot wholly satisfy myself that the shack is the
one we are looking for. Do you agree with Mr. Moran that its construction is so un-
usual as to erase all doubts? I await news from you with eagerness, but you will see
why I don't know just how far to go in signing an option or buying the shack or making
a final move until I have seen the Rojas family notes and have heard further from you
or Moran, or both. You and Mr. Moran have been so wonderfully helpful that I can no
longer take your suggestion that I write up the paper “The true location of Camp
Lazear” under my own name alone, merely acknowledging your help. The help of yourself
and Moran has been so crucial and so wonderful that you both must be co-authors whenever
I get around to writing it up. I will leave for Washington, Pa. on October 23, will be
here till then, and can be reached at the George Washington Hotel, Washington, Pa.
October 25 and 26, then back here.
